search_input: FLOOR. . . staking the claim of civilization on the raw ground, encoding usage and assuming decoration. The textural details of previous occupants are kept intact. Featureless and soundless (except for sneakers, which squeak on it). Despite this, the language of space planning is the floor plan, and its graphic qualities cannot be entirely ignored. As one moved from floor to floor, the iconography seems to have been the constitutive, rather than coincidental, part of the architecture, and together, they transform the building.
suggested_query: Its lines and curves, usually a background, here take the foreground, a visual representation of the space's organization. This surface, often overlooked, is now the site of a new narrative, as the inhabitants of the room begin to leave their mark.  |
